I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on the proposed 
Energy Efficiency Multi-project Financing Program (the Program) for the issue of partial credit 
guarantees (PCGs) by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to selected financial institutions (the 
Partner Banks) in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) to cover a portion of the principal 
payments due to these banks under loans to energy efficiency projects, up to an aggregate 
amount of CNY800 million.  
 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Energy Efficiency in the People’s Republic of China 
1.  Recent Trends  
 
2.  Energy demand in the PRC, the world’s second-largest energy consumer and one of its 
largest emitters of greenhouse gases (GHGs), is growing rapidly to support the economic 
growth needed to raise the living standards of the large population. Between 1980 and 2000, 
PRC achieved a quadrupling of its gross domestic product (GDP) with only a doubling of energy 
consumption,  effectively  decoupling  the  relationship  between  economic  growth  and  energy 
consumption.  However,  during  PRC’s  transition  to  a  market-based  economy,  many  of  the 
country’s energy efficiency programs were dismantled between 2001 and 2005. Since 2001, 
accordingly, energy use has outpaced economic growth, with elasticity reaching 1.6 in 2004. 
The growth in energy consumption moderated to some extent in 2005 but averaged a high 9.5% 
yearly in 2000–2005, only slightly lower than GDP growth, resulting in elasticity of just under 1, 
versus the 0.4–0.5 in 1980–2000. Continuation of this 1:1 ratio of energy consumption to GDP, 
given the PRC’s stated goal of again quadrupling GDP in 2000–2020, will lead to significant 
demand for energy, most of it coal-based; 82% of electricity is now produced by burning coal. 
The resulting local, national, and global environmental impact could be substantial. 
 
3.  The  current  energy  path  is  neither  environmentally  nor  economically  sustainable. 
Increasing the efficiency of energy use, to wring more service value from each primary energy 
unit consumed, has large environmental and economic benefit. Energy efficiency is essential, to 
reduce  global  emissions  of  GHGs,  ease  growth  in  fossil  energy  demand  and  the  upward 
pressure  on  energy  prices,  and  improve  energy  security.  Investments  in  energy  efficiency 
technologies in the rapidly growing economies are required, to prevent being locked into an 
energy-intensive capital stock in the future. The benefits of energy efficiency are described in 
Appendix 2.  
  2.  Demand-Side Efficiency Potential 
 
4.  Energy efficiency means delivering services with less primary energy. Energy efficiency 
projects are defined as economic investments in energy equipment and infrastructure that 
deliver higher useful energy outputs or services. Reducing energy use creates a compounded 
efficiency increase throughout the energy value chain. This is evident in the case of electricity, 
where overall network and system losses and inefficiencies, from production to end-use, 100 
units of input energy to only 9.5 units of actual energy service at the point of end use. As such, a 
small increase in demand-side efficiency will reverse the compounding losses. It results in both 
lower  energy  consumption  and  reduced  emissions  of  GHGs.  The  technical  and  economic

2   
 
potential exists to save 20–40% of energy use, with cost-effective investments in a broad range 
of applications, such as in motors, which account for about 50% of power use, heating and air-
conditioning, controls, water supply, lighting, and efficient combustion systems. 
 
5.  Improvements in demand-side efficiency are required across all sectors—commercial, 
industrial, governmental, agricultural, residential, and transport. In addition, specific electricity 
consumption in the products is much higher in the PRC compared with international standards. 
To achieve its economic and environmental target, the PRC needs to attract a huge investment 
in energy efficiency technologies and practices. The Energy Research Institute of the National 
Development and Reform Commission estimates the investment needs by 2010 to be at least 
$120–$160 billion.  
 
3.  Policies and Regulations 
 
6.  Improving energy efficiency has been a cornerstone of the PRC’s energy policy for 
20 years. In the 1980s, the Government employed a monitoring and quota mechanism through 
the planned economy to promote energy conservation and curtail at least the most blatant 
cases of energy waste. As recently as the 1990s the number of energy efficiency projects that 
received funding was determined by a top-down approach that largely depended on state 
subsidies. State-owned banks were instructed to finance projects selected by the Government.  
 
7.  When the PRC began its transition toward a market economy, however, the Government 
made  significant  changes  that  affected  energy  efficiency.  It  reformed  the  banking  sector, 
liberalized energy prices, and phased out subsidies for energy efficiency projects. 
 
8.  Faced with the recent energy intensity increase since 2001, the Government recognizes 
the urgency to invest in and significantly improve energy efficiency. From its previous emphasis 
on  energy  exploitation,  the  national  energy  policy  now  assigns  top  priority  to  energy 
conservation and energy efficiency. Expanding investment in energy efficiency projects, among 
others, is a high priority for environmental sustainability and enterprise competitiveness. The 
Government seeks to promote market-based methods to deliver and finance energy efficiency 
projects, in partnership with the private sector.  
 
9.  The  11th  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010)  strengthens  the  policy  orientation  to  energy 
conservation, high-efficiency use, and energy security. The large energy efficiency potential is 
seen as a great opportunity to obtain some flexibility in the PRC’s dependency on external 
sources of energy. By the end of this period, the Government aims to improve energy intensity 
by  20%  and  reduce  sulfur  dioxide  (SO )  emissions  by  10%  compared  with  2005  levels. 
2
Achieving these targets requires major policy changes that would both revitalize investment in 
energy efficiency throughout the PRC and encourage the shift to less energy-intensive and 
more economically productive sectors. A number of steps have been taken to support this 
target. The Medium- and Long-Term Energy Conservation Plan highlights key sectors and 
provides a conceptual road map for improving energy efficiency. The plan puts forward 10 
specific types of energy efficiency projects, and identifies the industry, transport, and building 
sectors as having the most potential for energy efficiency improvement. In addition, energy 
efficiency  is  granted  special  attention  along  with  energy  development  in  all  energy-related 
planning  by  the  Government.  The  Energy  Conservation  Law  is  being  revised  and  a 
comprehensive Energy Law is expected to be in effect by 2008.  
 
10.  Furthermore, the PRC’s highest governing bodies have made resource conservation a 
strategic focal point for future economic development. The State Council has called for the

3 
establishment of a “resource-saving society” and emphasized every citizen’s duty to conserve 
energy and other resources. National standards are being developed for energy efficiency 
monitoring and evaluation, verification, and labeling.  
B.  Energy Efficiency Financing 
11.  Despite the recent policy shift in favor of energy efficiency, market barriers still limit the 
expansion of energy efficiency projects. One of the key bottlenecks is lack of access to finance. 
The reluctance of banks to finance energy efficiency projects is often cited as a key obstacle to 
scaling up energy efficiency project implementation. According to recent surveys and comments 
obtained  through  ADB’s  Energy  Efficiency  Initiative  (EEI)  consultation  process,  the  main 
reasons why financially viable energy efficiency projects fail to attract commercial bank loans in 
the PRC are summarized as follows: 
 
(i)  Energy efficiency projects involve a wide range of technologies with which the 
commercial  banks  are  often  unfamiliar.  There  is  gap  in  energy  efficiency 
knowledge and misperceptions of actual technology risks. Commercial banks 
have  not  yet  developed  sufficient  technical  knowledge  and  experience.  No 
specific  training  system  exists.  As  a  result,  that  there  is  little  marketing, 
evaluation, and structuring of energy efficiency projects. 
 
(ii)  Management  awareness  about  energy  efficiency  financing  is  low,  and  no 
effective financing model for energy efficiency projects has been developed in 
the market. Few management resources have therefore been allocated for this 
purpose. 
  
(iii)  The  due  diligence  costs  associated  with  energy  efficiency  projects  are  high 
because of the need for technical evaluation regardless of the project size. 
  
(iv)  Availability of medium- and long-term loans, even for 3–5 years, is very limited. 
 
(v)  The local banking sector is highly liquid, but financing is often based on high 
collateralization,  making  it  difficult  for  energy  end  users  to  raise  financing. 
Substantial credit enhancement is needed to meet the security requirements of 
local commercial banks. 
 
12.  A window of opportunity exists for ADB to make a real impact in this sector in the PRC. 
By mobilizing available domestic funds in an effective investment program, ADB can help 
support energy efficiency investment and create better awareness among commercial banks. 
The program approach, broad in reach, will enable ADB to provide financing support for a large 
number of energy efficiency projects, which are often too small for ADB to finance directly.  
C.  ADB’s Operations 
1.  Country Strategy 
 
13.  ADB’s  country  strategy  for  the  PRC  is  based  on  four  development  objectives: 
(i) equitable  and  inclusive  growth,  (ii)  better  and  more  efficient  markets,  (iii)  environmental 
improvements, and (iv) regional cooperation.

4   
 
14.  To support the initiatives taken by the Government to let the private sector contribute as 
the driving force for long-term economic growth and job creation, ADB plans to substantially 
increase its private sector operations in the PRC, particularly in the infrastructure and energy 
sectors, the financial sector, and environmental improvements. In the infrastructure and energy 
sectors, ADB prioritizes pioneering projects with innovative contractual and financial structuring 
to encourage private sector participation and enhance management expertise.  
2.  Medium-Term Strategy II  
15.  ADB’s Medium-Term Strategy II (2006–2008) seeks more directly to help DMCs acquire 
low-carbon technologies, and to implement energy efficiency and renewable energy projects to 
enable Asia to take the technology leap. Catalyzing investment to improve the investment 
climate, expanding private sector operations, and managing the environment are also priorities. 
3.  Energy Sector Strategy 
16.  ADB’s energy sector strategy supports, as operational priorities, (i) poverty reduction, 
through such means as energy infrastructure development for sustainable economic growth, 
and increased access to energy for the poor, particularly in rural areas; (ii) private sector 
involvement, through energy sector restructuring and the creation of an enabling environment 
for the private sector to invest and operate; (iii) regional and global environment impact, through 
measures that address acid rain problems and promote the use of clean energy; and (iv) 
regional cooperation. The ongoing review of ADB’s energy policy is expected to recommend 
greater focus on energy efficiency. 
4.  The Energy Efficiency Initiative 
17.  ADB’s EEI aims to expand ADB operations in energy efficiency and clean energy to at 
least $1 billion a year, according to the general framework for the implementation of EEI.  
 
18.  The EEI task force has identified the PRC as a priority DMC with the highest potential 
among DMCs in Asia and the Pacific for energy efficiency and clean energy investments. The 
task force has been holding consultative meetings in the PRC to learn firsthand from energy 
efficiency market stakeholders’ about immediate investment opportunities and barriers in the 
PRC  market  as  a  prerequisite  for  developing  energy  efficiency  projects.  EEI  consultations 
confirmed  many  different  approaches  are  needed  to  tap  various  segments  with  significant 
energy efficiency potential. ADB has developed several projects under the EEI in the PRC. In its 
public sector operations, ADB is working with a provincial government to provide a financial 
intermediation loan to a provincial trust company to finance energy efficiency in the industrial 
sector (multitranche financing facility for the Guangdong Energy Efficiency and Environment 
Improvement Investment Program). In the private sector, in addition to the proposed Program, 
ADB has called for proposals from private equity funds interested in equity investment in clean 
energy and energy efficiency projects in the region. 
 
19.  The  proposed  Program  responds  to  a  request  from  EEI  task  force  to  design  and 
implement a new risk-sharing methodology in order to facilitate investments in energy efficiency 
projects. Ongoing consultation with a wide range of stakeholders has enabled ADB to develop 
the Program as a pilot project to address the financing needs of a series of small and medium 
scale energy efficiency projects.

5 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
20.  The impact of the Program is to expand private sector investment in energy efficiency 
projects in the PRC by developing the energy efficiency financing activities of qualified financial 
institutions (Partner Banks), thereby achieving energy efficiency improvements and associated 
reduction in the growth of GHGs and other pollutants. To achieve this objective, the Program 
will provide PCGs that will enable commercial banks to offer energy end users access to energy 
efficiency financing at reliable and reasonable terms and conditions.  
 
21.  Energy efficiency investments are needed in a range of market segments and each 
sector has distinct credit characteristics and investment needs. Since the commercial banks 
have limited experience in energy efficiency financing, the Program will focus on a specific area 
to accelerate learning among the banks. Consultations have led to the selection of the energy 
efficiency of buildings as the initial target market on the basis of market potential as well as the 
commercial  banks’  interest,  appetite,  and  capacity.  Energy  efficiency  of  buildings  can  be 
achieved with proven technologies and has significant improvement potential. Yet this market 
has been neglected because of relatively more attention being focused on improving industry 
energy efficiency. Urban areas are responsible for about 75% of all energy use and GHG 
emission in the world. Buildings account for nearly 40% of GHG emissions worldwide. Improving 
energy efficiency in buildings with appropriate technologies locks in the pattern of energy use for 
many  years.  Given  the  PRC’s  rapid  urbanization,  energy  efficiency  of  buildings  will  have 
long-lasting and large cumulative impact. The Program will provide energy end users with 
access to the necessary funds to retrofit existing buildings with energy-saving improvements 
and install energy-efficient products in their buildings, typically leading to energy savings of 20–
40%. 
B.  Description 
1.  The Program 
 
22.  The Program will set up systems and framework agreements to provide energy end user 
with increased access to finance for energy efficiency projects that have so far not been fully 
addressed through local financing. ADB will provide a PCG to each Partner Bank to cover the 
credit risks associated with energy efficiency projects, thereby mobilizing their funds for energy 
efficiency projects. The lack of technical competence among commercial banks to make a 
technical assessment of energy efficiency projects is a key bottleneck. Thus, combining the 
technical skills of a private sector energy management company (Technical Partner) with ADB 
risk-sharing is a key innovation under the Program.  
 
23.  Each energy efficiency project financed by a Partner Bank under the Program will benefit 
from comprehensive technical input from the Technical Partner throughout the project cycle. 
The Technical Partner will take the lead in marketing, energy audit, technical due diligence, 
setting the energy policy for end users, and equipment procurement. The Technical Partner will 
source the projects to be financed by a Partner Bank for credit assessment and further due 
diligence. Each eligible energy efficiency loan is subject to detailed technical review by the 
Technical Partner and credit assessment and approval by the relevant Partner Bank.

6   
 
C.  The Credit Guarantee  
1.  Rationale 
 
24.  Commercial banks in the PRC tend to lend mainly against fixed asset collateral as 
opposed to the prospective project cash flow and debt service capacity. This approach often 
limits the market for commercial bank financing. Because of lack of experience, the banks often 
perceive the risk of lending for energy efficiency purposes to be higher than the actual risks. The 
Program is intended to help close this gap. It will support projects that are viable but lack access 
to  finance  under  current  lending  practices.  Energy  efficiency  projects  can  often  pay  for 
themselves from energy cost savings, but these projects generally lack collateral value, as the 
equipment is engineered for and installed at the energy user’s facilities and is difficult to remove 
and use economically in other locations. The Program will help address this barrier to energy 
efficiency finance by providing a substitute for collateral value, allowing the commercial banks to 
underwrite financing on the basis of the economic merits and cash flows of energy efficiency 
projects. With the credit enhancement tool to be provided by the Program, Partner Banks can 
prudently extend their risk horizons, enter new markets, and offer loans for energy efficiency 
projects at reliable and reasonable terms and conditions. 
 
  2.  Scope of the Guarantee 
25.  Each PCG will cover an agreed portion of the principal amount financed by the relevant 
Partner Bank under the relevant energy efficiency loans. ADB’s aggregate liability under the 
Program will be limited to CNY800 million. ADB will agree on the lending selection criteria and 
risk management process with each Partner Bank. Once ADB is satisfied with the record of a 
Partner Bank and its borrowers, portfolio targets may be revised to encourage the Partner Bank 
to expand to new customer segments.  
 
  3.  Eligibility Criteria and Use of Proceeds 
26.  The  PCG  covers  both  the  retrofitting  of  existing  buildings  with  energy  efficiency 
technology and equipment and also the financing of new buildings, such as green buildings, 
with improved arrangements for more efficient energy use. The Program will consider energy 
efficiency projects that (i) have energy efficiency potential, as confirmed through an energy audit 
by the Technical Partner; and (ii) are creditworthy, as evaluated and approved by the applicable 
Partner Bank. Eligible energy efficiency projects will be selected according to the preagreed 
minimum criteria. These eligibility criteria and procedures will be adopted by each Partner Bank. 
Energy efficiency loans that involve land acquisition or resettlement will not be considered. 
Loans  provided  under  the  Program  will  be  used  to  fund  all  costs  associated  with  energy 
efficiency projects: (i) energy equipment and systems, (ii) installation costs; (iii) engineering 
costs; (iv) financing costs and fees; and (v) project development costs. 
 
D.  Program Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Selection and Approval of Partner Banks 
 
27.  Partner Banks will be selected at the sole discretion of ADB. Before final selection, each 
Partner Bank will be subject to detailed due diligence and credit analysis. The standardized 
credit review of each Partner Bank will include an analysis of capital adequacy, asset quality,

7 
liquidity, connected or large lending, and profitability. It will also include a review of ownership, 
integrity,  governance,  money  laundering  controls,  credit  approval  process,  and  operating 
capacity.  
  3.  Reporting and Management 
28.  Each Partner Bank will be required to follow a pre-agreed and standardized format both 
for loan documentation and for regular reporting. It must promptly notify ADB of any defaults in 
the portfolio.  
 
IV.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACT, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Justification 
 
29.  The  Program  is  justified  by  its  development  impact  and  demonstration  effects.  It 
supports the Government’s development plans, ADB’s operational strategies, and the value 
added of ADB’s participation.  
 
(i)  The  Program  will  support  the  Government’s  policy  of  promoting  a  resource-
saving society by bridging the gap between the substantial level of investment 
required  in  energy  efficiency  projects  and  the  limited  financing  capacity  of 
commercial banks. It addresses and is aligned with the Government’s strategic 
priorities for energy and environment as set forth in the 11th Five-Year Plan.  
 
(ii)  The  Program  will  embody  ADB’s  country  strategy  for  the  PRC,  which 
emphasizes supporting environmental improvement. The Program introduces a 
new  mechanism  for  efficiently  addressing  demand-side  energy  management, 
which  helps  to  arrest  environmental  degration,  and  advance  sustainable 
development without sacrificing the standard of living. 
 
(iii)  The Program is consistent with ADB’s private sector operations policy in the 
PRC, which is focused on the infrastructure and energy sectors, the financial 
sector,  and  environmental  improvements.  This  Program  contributes  to  the 
introduction  and  transfer  of  state-of-the-art  technology  and  management 
know-how to be used in dealing with energy management in the PRC.  
 
(iv)  The Program is in line with ADB’s energy sector strategy, which recommends a 
reorientation  of  energy  sector  activities  to  address  regional  and  global 
environmental  impact.  By  introducing  energy  efficiency,  the  Program  will 
contribute to mitigating climate change. The proposed guarantee structure is a 
multi-obligor guarantee in local currency with a clear thematic intervention for 
energy efficiency, consistent with ADB’s credit enhancement operations policy. 
 
(v)  The Program will embody ADB’s EEI and Innovation and Efficiency Initiative, 
which recommends the introduction of new forms of cofinancing through active 
risk-sharing with commercial financing partners.

8   
 
B.  Development Impact  
30.  The Program is designed to promote economic growth and environmental improvement 
in the PRC through improved energy efficiency. The impacts of improving energy efficiency in 
the PRC will decrease in the growth rate of GHG emissions, increase energy services, and 
improve energy security. Specifically, the Program will (i) demonstrate the potential for energy 
efficiency in retrofitted and new buildings, which are untapped areas of energy efficiency, and 
set standards for competitors to follow; (ii) improve global and local environmental conditions 
through improved energy efficiency; (iii) support the Government’s efforts to build a resource-
saving society through private sector participation; (iv) help remove barriers to investments in 
energy efficiency, thereby promoting enterprise competitiveness and economic growth; and 
(v) demonstrate that energy efficiency projects are bankable and encourage the private sector 
to invest in energy efficiency beyond the Program’s intervention. 
 
31.  The  development  impact  of  the  Program  will  be  assessed  and  described  from  the 
perspective of development effectiveness and Program framework, and its contribution to both 
economic sustainability and private sector development as per guidelines for the implementation 
of  the  Good  Practice  Standards  for  Evaluation  of  Private  Sector  Investment  Operations 
prepared by the Evaluation Cooperation Group of the multilateral development banks. It is 
deemed  to  be  developmentally  effective,  and  its  performance  measurable.  A  summary 
discussion of each of these assessment parameters follows. 
  1.  Program Performance 
32.  The Program will be assessed against its specific investment capital, operational and 
financial objectives. Effectiveness will be measured in terms of how successfully the Program 
attracts private sector investment in energy efficiency, and leads to annual energy savings and 
reductions in GHG emissions.  
2.  Economic Sustainability 
33.  The Program will be assessed for economic sustainability, by evaluating its ability to 
develop and implement energy efficiency infrastructure and contribute to sustainable growth. 
The Program’s successful implementation will promote retrofitted and green buildings in the 
PRC. 
 
3.  Private Sector Development 
 
34.  The Program will be assessed by its contribution to private sector development. This 
assessment will focus on the Program’s commercial and financial viability, and its demonstrative 
and catalytic effect on future private sector participation in energy efficiency and the economy 
as a whole. 
 
35.  The Program will not be specifically assessed from an investment profitability point of 
view, as a profitability assessment is better gauged and measured against a portfolio of similar 
loans  and  equity  investments.  Similarly,  the  Program  will  not  be  assessed  and  measured 
against overall operational effectiveness, as this is a department-wide consideration.

9 
C.  Environmental Aspects and Social Dimensions 
1.  ADB Safeguards 
 
36.  The Program has been classified environmental category FI and assigned as category C 
with respect to indigenous people and resettlement. Each Partner Bank will set up and maintain 
an environmental management system (EMS) for new projects and build capacity to implement 
the system. At least one bank officer will attend ADB-sponsored training in environmental 
management.  
2.  Clean Development Mechanism 
37.  Energy savings provide an environmentally sound solution to reduce GHG emissions 
such as carbon dioxide (CO ) and have the potential to generate carbon credits under the Clean 
2
Development Mechanism (CDM). The CDM is a market-based arrangement under the Kyoto 
Protocol  that  allows  industrialized  countries  with  GHG  reduction  commitment  to  purchase 
carbon credits from developing countries to meet their commitment. The Program will support 
the energy end users in exploring possibilities for generating carbon revenue from their projects 
during the feasibility studies, and will also seek assistance from ADB’s Carbon Market Initiative 
for this purpose. The additional carbon revenue will assist in removing the barriers to energy 
efficiency projects. 
D.  Anticorruption Policy; Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of 
Terrorism 
38.  Each Partner Bank will be advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to 
date) and the policy relating to the Combating of Money Laundering and the Financing of 
Terrorism  (2003).  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance,  accountability,  and 
transparency, ADB will require each Partner Bank to institute, maintain, and comply with internal 
procedures and controls following international best practice standards for preventing corruption 
or money laundering activities or the financing of terrorism, and covenant with ADB to refrain 
from engaging in such activities. The credit guarantee documentation between ADB and each 
Partner Bank will further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these 
undertakings. 
VI.  ASSURANCES 
39.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Articles of 
Agreement),  the  Government  will  be  requested  to  confirm  that  it  has  no  objection  to  the 
proposed assistance to the Program. No funds will be disbursed until ADB receives such 
confirmation.  
VII.  RECOMMENDATION 
40.  I am satisfied that the proposed credit guarantee would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the

10  
 
Board approve the issue of credit guarantees in an aggregate amount of up to CNY800,000,000 
in favor of selected financial institutions without government counterguarantee for the Energy 
Efficiency Multi-project  Financing Program  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  on  such 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and 
as may be reported to the Board. 
 
  Liqun Jin 
  Vice President 
 
20 November 2007

14       Appendix 2 
BENEFITS OF ENERGY EFFICIENCY1
A.  Overview 
 
1.  The impacts of improving energy efficiency in Asia-Pacific will be a lower growth rate of 
CO2 emissions, increased energy services, and improved energy security. The slowdown in 
CO  emissions will help reduce the adverse impact of climate change and promote sustainable 
2
economic growth. Such impact merits support from both developed and developing countries. 
The rationale for energy efficiency must be firmly established to sustain political will and long-
term investment focus at the required scale. Investments in energy efficiency can be justified 
and pursued to the extent of their economic merits. This is known as the no-regrets strategy, 
which means that making energy efficiency investments that are economically viable now, 
irrespective of their long-term environmental benefits, can later create no regrets if predicted 
climate change impacts do not occur.  
 
2.  Energy efficiency has a large technical and economic potential, at a scale that can 
contribute substantially to meeting future demands for energy services. The economy does not 
need  energy  per  se,  but  rather  energy  services—transport,  heating,  cooling,  drive  power, 
refrigeration, pumping, lighting, etc. Energy efficiency means delivering the services with less 
primary  energy.  Technological  development  already  does  this;  over  the  years  the  energy 
intensity in industrialized countries has substantially improved. The International Energy Agency 
has argued that energy efficiency needs to be viewed like other energy sources; it estimates 
that without the energy savings in the 25-year period from 1973 to 1998, the Organisation for 
Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries would have been almost 50% 
higher, which makes the contribution of energy efficiency greater than that of oil and coal. 
Further, energy efficiency can be exploited faster, more cheaply, and with employment that 
generates domestic economic growth and investment. 
B.  Energy Efficiency Benefits 
3.  Capital Stock Turnover Rates. Each investment in infrastructure for energy supply and 
energy-using  equipment  locks  in  the  pattern  of  primary  energy  use  for  many  years. 
Infrastructure  for  energy-intensive  industries  such  as  steel,  cement,  aluminum,  and  power 
generation and transmission, lasts 20–40 years. It follows that energy efficiency investments 
would also have a long-lived and large cumulative impact. 
 
4.  Macroeconomic Benefits. Energy efficiency reduces fossil fuel consumption, thereby 
lowering fossil fuel imports (saving foreign currency) and trade deficits, reducing vulnerability to 
oil price volatility, and improving overall international competitiveness (in the face of high energy 
prices).  Employment  and  domestic  job  growth  are  also  associated  with  energy  efficiency. 
Market-wide declines in fossil fuel demand can create a downward pressure on international 
fuel prices, or diminish upward price trends, resulting in lower or more stable prices to the 
benefit of the region’s economies, which are generally net fossil fuel consumers. 
 
5.  Air Pollution and Health. When linked to a reduction in coal use in urban areas, energy 
efficiency reduces urban air pollution and generates quantifiable public health benefits.  
 
                                                 
 
1  Based on ADB. 2006. Report on Energy Efficiency Initiative. Manila.

Appendix 2  15 
6.  Enterprise Benefits. Energy efficiency results in economic benefits to energy users at 
the enterprise level. Many energy efficiency projects have compelling economics, with savings 
of 20–40% of energy use in a given application and simple payback periods in the range of 2–3 
years. Yet these investments have remained largely undeveloped because of various market 
and  institutional  barriers.  By  reducing  energy  use  per  unit  of  output  or  service  delivered, 
enterprises save money, reduce maintenance costs, increase productivity, and improve product 
quality (energy efficiency often involves upgrading technology). 
 
7.  Achieving  the  Development  Goals  of  Developing  Member  Countries.  Energy 
efficiency projects can contribute to reducing poverty and meeting the development goals of 
developing  member  countries  because  they  are  often  the  least-cost  means  for  expanding 
energy services and allowing the population to enjoy a high quality of life with less primary 
resource consumption overall—a key to long-term sustainability.

16     Appendix 3 
GOVERNMENT POLICIES AND REGULATORY FRAMEWORK 
A.  Top-Down Energy Efficiency Policy 
 
1.  Improving energy efficiency has been a cornerstone of the energy policy of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) for 20 years. In the 1980s, the Government employed a monitoring 
and quota mechanism through the planned economy to promote energy conservation and 
curtail at least the most blatant cases of energy waste. As late as the 1990s the number of 
energy efficiency projects that received funding was determined by a top-down approach that 
depended largely on state subsides. State-owned banks were instructed to finance projects 
selected by the Government. The Energy Conservation Law, passed in 1997, was intended to 
facilitate energy saving, improve the efficiency of energy use, protect the environment, and 
guarantee national economic and social development. It calls for increased efficiency of energy 
use and encourages the development and use of new sources of energy. Accordingly, energy-
using entities must “strengthen energy management, and formulate and implement technical 
measures  for  energy  savings.”  The  Circular  of  the  State  Council  on  the  View  of  Further 
Developing  the  Comprehensive  Resource  Utilization  (Guo  Fa,  August  1996,  No.  36)  is 
supplementary to the law and emphasizes the key field of energy conservation.  
 
2.  When the PRC began its transition toward market economy, however, the Government 
made a variety of significant changes that affected energy efficiency. It reformed the banking 
sector, liberalizing energy prices, and phasing out subsidies for energy efficiency projects.  
B.  Market-Based Energy Efficiency Policy 
3.  Faced with the recent energy intensity increase since 2001, the Government recognizes 
the urgency of the need for significant improvements and investments in energy efficiency. A 
shift  in  the  national  energy  policy  has  assigned  first  priority  to  energy  conservation  and 
improved  energy  efficiency  from  the  previous  emphasis  on  energy  exploitation.  Expanded 
investment in energy efficiency projects, among others, is a high priority for environmental 
sustainability and enterprise competitiveness. The Government seeks to promote market-based 
methods to deliver and finance energy efficiency projects, in partnership with the private sector.  
 
4.  The  10th  Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005)  set  the  goals  of  improving  the  energy 
infrastructure, increasing the share of energy provided by natural gas, and reducing coal use 
through various measures, including energy conservation and efficiency.  
 
5.  The 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010) further strengthens the policy orientation toward 
energy  conservation,  high-efficiency  use,  and  energy  security.  The  high  energy  efficiency 
potential is seen as a great opportunity to obtain some flexibility in the country’s dependency on 
external sources of energy. By the end of the plan period, the PRC Government aims to achieve 
a  20%  improvement  in  energy  intensity  compared  with  2005  levels.  Achieving  this  target 
requires  major  policy  changes  that  would  both  revitalize  investment  in  energy  efficiency 
throughout the PRC and encourage the shift to less energy-intensive and more economically 
productive sectors. The plan aims to achieve structural, technical, and management of energy 
conservation  through  an  optimized  industrial  structure,  wide  use  of  energy  conservation 
technology,  and  strengthened  systems  in  the  energy  production,  transportation,  and 
consumption industries and other industries. Chapter 12 of the plan, related to the energy 
industry,  emphasizes  pluralistic  and  optimal  development  to  secure  a  stable,  economically 
sustainable, clean, and safe energy supply system.

Appendix 3  17 
6.  A number of steps have been taken to support the achievement of the 20% reduction 
target. The related administrative regulations include the Circular of the General Office of the 
National  Development  Reform  Commission  on  Organizing  and  Implementing  the  National 
Development  of  Important  Industries  and  Technologies  in  Energy  Conservation  and  Key 
Technologies of Renewable Energies (September 2004), the Circular of the General Office of 
the State Council on Further Pushing the Innovation of Wall Materials and Popularizing the 
Building of Energy Conservation (Guo Ban Fa, June 2005, No. 33), and the Circular of the 
General Office of the State Council on the View of Encouraging the Development for the Energy 
Efficient, Environmental Friendly and Low Emission Vehicles (Guo Ban Fa, December 2005, 
No. 61). Most importantly, the Medium- and Long-Term Energy Conservation Plan highlights 
key sectors of emphasis and provides a conceptual road map for improving energy efficiency. 
The plan puts forward 10 specific types of energy efficiency projects, and identifies the sectors 
with the most potential for energy efficiency improvement. Energy efficiency is also granted 
special attention along with energy development in all of the Government’s energy-related 
planning. In addition, the Energy Conservation Law is being revised and a comprehensive 
Energy Law is expected to be in effect by 2008. The revised Energy Conservation Law will 
(i) specify the enforcement authority; (ii) broaden the field of energy conservation; (iii) provide 
concrete  measures  for  energy  pricing,  financing,  and  taxation  or  fiscal  budgeting;  and 
(iv) provide stricter punishment. 
 
7.  Furthermore,  the  PRC’s  highest-level  governing  bodies  have  defined  resource 
conservation as a strategic focal point for the PRC’s future economic development. In this vein, 
the  State  Council  has  called  for  the  establishment  of  a  “resource-saving  society”  and 
emphasized every citizen’s duty to conserve energy and other recourses.  
 
8.  In 2004, the PRC’s Initial National Communication to the United Nations Framework 
Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) stated that “A key component of the PRC’s industrial 
policies is to reduce consumption of energy and other resources, improve the comprehensive 
utilization and efficient use of energy and other resources, promote cleaner production, and 
prevent and control industrial pollution.” It added: “The Chinese government has all along 
attached great importance to international cooperation in the field of climate change.” National 
standards for energy efficiency monitoring and evaluation, verification, and labeling are being 
developed. 
 
9.  In  April  2006  the  Government  launched  the  Top-1000  Program  to  improve  energy 
efficiency in industrial enterprises. The top 1,000 enterprises were in the following industries: 
(i) building  materials,  (ii)  power,  (iii)  textile,  (iv)  iron  and  steel,  (v)  chemical,  (vi)  coal, 
(vii) petroleum and petrochemical, (viii) nonferrous metal, and (ix) paper. Each enterprise is 
supposed to sign an energy efficiency agreement with the Government set energy efficiency 
goals, implement an energy utilization reporting system, conduct energy audits, draw up an 
energy conservation plan, invest in energy efficiency improvement, and train its officials and 
staff in energy efficiency.  
 
10.  The Decision of the State Council on Strengthening Energy Conservation (Guo Fa, 
August, 2006, No. 28) places energy conservation in a position of greater strategic urgency to 
ensure the fulfillment of the energy conservation goals of the 11th Five-Year Plan. Overall 
energy  consumption  in  key  industries  should  reach  internationally  advanced  levels.  The 
decision  reiterates  the  main  goals  of  energy  conservation,  which  are  to  (i)  lower  the 
consumption of each CNY 10,000 GDP to 0.98 tons of standard coal, about 20% less than at 
the  end  of  the  10th  Five-Year  Plan  Period;  and  (ii)  achieve  an  annual  average  energy 
conservation efficiency of 4.4%. The decision also explicitly asks all areas and departments to

18   Appendix 3   
 
 
adopt  the  following  measures  to  meet  the  energy  conservation  goal:  (i)  revise  industry 
structures and build energy-saving industrial systems by increasing the proportion of the service 
industry in the national economy, strictly controlling the growth of industries with high energy 
consumption, and developing high-efficiency, clean, and renewable sources of energy; (ii) focus 
on energy conservation in key fields, including energy-consuming industries, residential and 
public buildings, transportation, commercial and civilian fields, rural areas, and government 
departments;  (iii)  pursue  the  development  of  energy  conservation  technologies  and  the 
implementation  of  the  10  energy  conservation  projects  in  the  11th  Five-Year  Plan; 
(iv) strengthen energy conservation supervision and administration; and (v) establish energy 
conservation  guarantee  mechanisms  comprising  energy  price  reforms,  preferential  taxation 
policies, and a reward system for energy conservation.  
 
11.  In March 2007, Premier Wen Jiabao reported to National People’s Congress that eight 
measures would be implemented in 2007 to further improve energy conservation: (i) improve 
compliance  with  energy  consumption  standards,  (ii)  abolish  obsolete  production  capacity, 
(iii) prioritize  energy  conservation  in  high-consumption  sectors,  (iv)  improve  the  policy 
framework,  (v)  accelerate  technological  development,  (vi)  improve  pollution  control, 
(vii) strengthen the regulatory compliance system, and (viii) effectively delegate responsibility for 
energy conservation. CNY10 billion has been set aside for 2007 to be used in doing away with 
outdated production methods in industry, upgrading production technologies, and management 
of  high-energy-consuming  and  polluting  industries.  The  Integrated  Work  Plan  for  Energy 
Conservation and Emission Reduction issued by the State Council in June 2007 reconfirmed 10 
energy-saving projects during the period of the 11th Five Year Plan. The aim is to produce 240 
million tons of standard coal energy-saving capacity. 
 
12.  Preferential tax treatment policies for energy conservation were introduced in the new 
Enterprise  Income  Tax  Law.  Companies  that  engage  in  projects  involving  environmental 
protection,  energy  saving,  and  water  conservation  will  enjoy  income  tax  deductions  or 
exemption. Investment in the purchase of specialized equipment used in those projects can be 
offset against income tax at specified percentages. In addition, other tax benefits have been put 
in place, such as deduction of value-added tax for energy efficiency activities. It is anticipated 
that more detailed tax and fiscal policies will be issued to promote energy efficiency.  
 
13.  The  Notification  on  Enhanced  Carrying  out  of  Differential  Electricity  Prices  in 
September 2007  further  encourages  energy  efficiency  and  conservation.  Provincial 
Development and Reform Commissions, Economic and Trade Commissions, and Price Bureaus 
are  to  identify  high-energy-consuming  enterprises  and  remove  favorable  electricity  price 
incentives previously granted to those industries, especially the aluminum (removal of incentive 
of CNY0.02 or CNY0.05 by the end of 2007 and elimination of any remaining incentives in 
2008), iron alloy (removal of the incentive of CNY0.02 per kilowatt-hour by 21 October 2007) 
and chlorine-caustic soda (removal of incentives in 2008) industries.

Appendix 4           19 
 
  
ADB’S EFFORTS TO IMPROVE ENERGY EFFICIENCY 
A.  ADB in Asia and the Pacific1
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has made several investments in energy efficiency, 
including (i) a $150 million credit line for the Industrial Development Bank of India that was used 
for large industrial energy efficiency projects (1995); (ii) a $100 million credit line for the India 
Renewable  Energy  Development  Agency  (IREDA),  used  primarily  for  industrial  biomass 
cogeneration,  waste  heat  recovery,  and  wind  energy  projects  (1997);  and  (iii)  equity  fund 
investments in FondElec Global/Asia Clean Energy (FEGACE) Fund and China Environment 
Fund  (2003).  ADB  successfully  developed  the  Clean  Development  Mechanism  (CDM) 
transaction related to the coal-mine methane (CMM) capture project in Fuxin, People’s Republic 
of China (PRC); emission reduction credits from another two ADB projects in the PRC were sold 
directly by the project. Numerous energy efficiency investments have been made in power 
transmission and distribution system upgrades, which were components of mainstream power 
sector loans. Urban environment improvement and energy projects in the PRC, the Kyrgyz 
Republic,  and  Mongolia  include  projects  aimed  at  increasing  energy  efficiency  in  heat 
distribution and gas supply. These supply-side projects were generally rated satisfactory or 
partly satisfactory, except for the loan through a financial intermediary. 
 
2.  ADB has made a limited number of interventions on the demand-side energy efficiency; 
these were implemented in the 1990s mainly with the objective of improving the environment 
through the use of cleaner production technologies. Of the 11 such loans that were extended to 
industrial  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs),  nine  were  rated  successful  and  two  partially 
successful on completion. Continued and enhanced support for regulation to improve demand-
side efficiency is essential for reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. In markets where 
such policies and regulations exist but are not effective, further interventions will be required. To 
suitably address the concern related to market distortion, interventions can be designed for 
SOEs using the non-sovereign public sector financing facility (under ADB’s Innovation and 
Efficiency Initiative), which enables the use of market-based lending terms.  
 
3.  ADB  has  actively  promoted  energy  efficiency  in  the  region  through  its  technical 
assistance (TA) and capacity-building programs. Most recently, an interdepartmental program 
was established on Renewable Energy, Energy Efficiency and Climate Change (REACH). One 
of its key roles is to administer the following funds: (i) the Netherlands Cooperation Fund on 
Promotion  of  Investments  in  Developing  Member  Countries  (DMCs);  (ii)  the  Canadian 
Cooperation Fund on Greenhouse Gas Abatement, Adaptation, and Carbon Sequestration, 
which aims to help and engage ADB’s DMCs at the programming and policy level in managing 
and  abating  climate  change  to  reduce  the  growth  of  GHG  emissions;  (iii)  the  Danish 
Cooperation Fund on Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency in Rural Areas, which helps 
ADB promote environmental sustainability; and (iv) the Finnish Technical Assistance Grant 
Fund to support environmental protection and development of renewable energy These funds 
have been used to finance projects focused on advocacy, training, and capacity building and 
have also supported numerous energy efficiency project pre-feasibility studies, identifying cost-
effective investments, for example, in bagasse and rice husk cogeneration, agricultural and 
livestock waste biogas, and industrial efficiency. 
                                                 
 
1 Based on ADB. 2006. Report on Energy Efficiency Initiative. Manila.

20   Appendix 4 
   
 
4.  Overall, ADB’s level of investment in sustainable energy has so far been below both the 
potential and the need. Advocacy and training programs are useful, but success needs to be 
measured in terms of investments made, energy saved or produced, and emissions reduced. 
The current challenges call for ADB to increase its sustainable energy investing as a thematic 
area,  through  both targeted special energy efficiency projects and deeper incorporation of 
energy efficiency components within mainstream investments.  
B.   ADB in the People’s Republic of China 
5.  By 2006, ADB’s energy sector lending to the PRC exceeded $3.5 billion for 29 loans, 
which  had  successfully  facilitated  the  introduction  and  expansion  of  higher-risk  new 
technologies and new mechanisms, such as combined heat and power plants, CMM and coal-
bed methane (CBM) extraction, pumped storage power plants, emission trading mechanisms, 
500  kilovolt  transmission  lines,  gas  insulated  substations,  as  well  as  documentation  and 
transaction for CDM projects. Non-lending support of about $50 million has evolved from tariff 
reforms,  sector  restructuring,  establishment  of  the  electricity  regulator,  and  mainstreaming 
environment evaluation, to innovative technologies and mechanisms in energy efficiency and 
renewable energy, and to capacity building for CDM.  
 
6.  ADB assistance, in the form of policy advice, knowledge services, TA, project financing, 
and  risk  mitigation  services,  will  focus  on  (i)  energy  efficiency  and  energy  conservation; 
(ii) renewable energy, mainly wind, biomass, and hydropower; (iii) clean coal technologies; 
(iv) urban environment improvement; (v) CMM and CBM; and (vi) regional cooperation in power. 
ADB will also support the Government in intensifying sector reforms and building capacity 
(particularly at the provincial and project implementation level), nurturing a more efficient energy 
market  by  catalyzing  private  investment,  mobilizing  the  participation  of  domestic  financial 
institutions, stimulating CDM-related carbon trading, assisting local energy service companies, 
and removing major barriers to the transfer and adoption of low-carbon technologies.  
 
7.  In these focal areas, ADB will continue to conceptualize innovative projects and use new 
initiatives and flexible financing tools, e.g., the Carbon Market Initiative (CMI), the Clean Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility, the Energy Efficiency Initiative (EEI), financial intermediation, 
and multitranche financing facilities, in planning, designing, and implementing projects with 
tangible demonstration effects and significant opportunities for replication. Sector interventions 
will be closely coordinated with private sector operations, and will actively seek private or 
non-sovereign investment. Some projects targeted for the poor western provinces will directly 
benefit  local  rural  communities,  thereby  promoting  inclusive  growth.  ADB  assistance  will 
improve sector governance by adopting international best practices, ensuring efficient and fair 
procurement,  mainstreaming  participatory  project  design,  and  enhancing  compliance  with 
safeguards. 
 
8.   Many different approaches are needed to fully tap various segments with significant 
energy efficiency potential in the PRC. ADB has developed several projects under EEI. In its 
public sector operations, ADB is working with provincial government to provide a financial 
intermediation loan to a provincial trust company to finance energy efficiency in the industrial 
sector. In the private sector, in addition to the proposed Program, ADB has called for proposals 
from private equity funds interested in equity investment in clean energy and energy efficiency 
projects.
